description:
Talaromyces stipitatus ATCC 10500 is a species of filamentous fungi belonging to the genus Talaromyces. It is a member of the Ascomycota phylum, which is the largest phylum of fungi, known for their production of ascospores within a specialized structure called an ascus.

Talaromyces stipitatus ATCC 10500 is a common soil-dwelling fungus that has been extensively studied due to its potential for industrial and biotechnological applications. It is known to produce a variety of secondary metabolites, including the bioactive compound stipitatic acid, which has been investigated for its antimicrobial and antioxidant properties.

The fungus grows as a mold, forming a dense, velvety colony with a characteristic green to yellow-green color. Microscopically, it produces conidiophores (asexual spore-bearing structures) with flask-shaped phialides (specialized conidiogenous cells) that generate chains of smooth-walled, subglobose to ellipsoidal conidia (asexual spores).

Talaromyces stipitatus ATCC 10500 is a model organism for the study of fungal biology, taxonomy, and biodiversity, as well as its potential applications in various industries, such as the production of enzymes, biofuels, and bioactive compounds.
